awd_titl_txt: Leadership Support for Core Activities of the Board on Behavioral, Cognitive and Sensory Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
The National Academies of Sciences, Medicine and Engineering (The National Academies) in Washington, DC was chartered in 1863 with the mission of advising the government on scientific matters. The Board on Behavioral, Cognitive, and Sensory Sciences (BBCSS), set up with original funding from the National Science Foundation, has functioned as the primary voice for behavioral, cognitive, and sensory sciences for nearly 20 years within the National Academies and to external national and international stakeholders. BBCSS promotes cross-disciplinary inquiry into complex scientific and policy questions, draws attention to the behavioral sciences for national policy initiatives, and engages research scientists to develop a vision of where the behavioral sciences are headed.  It also provides a forum for objective, independent, and rigorous deliberation among researchers, the public, the media, Congress, professional associations, the National Science Foundation and other federal agencies in a variety of activities that it oversees.  

This award supports the core activites of the Board. BBCSS oversees numerous consensus studies, workshops, expert meetings, and seminars involving hundreds of volunteer experts drawn from the top echelons of the behavioral sciences. Several themes will be addressed in the five years covered by this award, including Reliable Science: Replicability, Reproducibility and Generalizability; Education and the Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences; Brain and Behavior Across the Life Span; and Social and Behavioral Sciences for National Security. Progress made on these themes (and additional ones that may emerge) can be tracked on the Board's publicly-accessible website.

por.por_cntn:
The Board on Behavioral, Cognitive, and Sensory Sciences (BBCSS) is a standing unit within the Division of Behavioral and Social Sciences and Education (DBASSE) at the National Academies of Sciences, Medicine and Engineering (The National Academies) in Washington, DC. The Board operates at the nexus between basic science and policy.  BBCSS was founded in 1997, with support from NSF, to promote cross-disciplinary inquiry into complex scientific and policy questions, to draw attention to the behavioral sciences for national policy initiatives, and to engage research scientists. BBCSS strives to create a vision for how the disciplines represented by the board can be leveraged to help address major national policy issues. BBCSS collaborates with other boards and units across the National Academies whose foci are on health, life, or physical sciences to ensure inclusion of and adequate representation for relevant behavioral, cognitive, and sensory science perspectives. 

Board activities are a primary focus of core leadership support. The Board met twice a year during this five-year award for a total of 10 meetings.  Those meetings provided a venue for board members to interface with representatives from federal agencies and advance discussions of important research topics of interest to the behavioral science community (e.g. replicability and reproducibility, living with dementia, advancing antiracism, diversity, equity, and inclusion in STEMM organizations). This was accomplished in both closed meetings consisting of only board members and staff as well as by hosting open discussions and seminars at board meetings.  NSF staff presented or participated in many of these meetings and engaged the academic and federal community on SBE’s work and vision. 

BBCSS provided oversight on numerous studies, workshops, and other activities under its purview whose funding came from various sources, including federal agencies and private foundations.  Notably, BBCSS also developed and provided oversight for several studies that received NSF project support.  These include some very impactful reports such as Reproducibility and Replicability in Science. This report is one of the most downloaded reports ever issued by The National Academies (in the top percentile). Toward the end of the grant period we released another highly impactful study, Advancing Antiracism, Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion in STEMM Organizations. Already in the first year after its release it has been one of the most impactful studies from the Academies in recent years (it is already in the top 3% of most-downloaded Academies reports) and is sought by federal agencies, university administrators, industry leaders, scientists, and practitioners alike.  It should be further noted that the board was highly successful in executing its mission despite the global pandemic that pivoted all of its work to a virtual platform.

BBCSS provides visibility and stature to behavioral, cognitive and sensory sciences across the federal government, within the National Academies, and to the other stakeholders such as scientists, industry leaders, academics, scientists, and the public.  This occurs naturally during the development and dissemination of reports as well as hosting public workshops and other events. Over the period of performance in this grant, there were also two special anniversary events that brought additional attention to the work of BBCSS and the continued importance of NSF support. These events also served to catalyze new directions for the years to come.

An important role of the Board Director that was facilitated by the core funding is representing behavioral, cognitive, and sensory science at The National Academies. Moreover, this funding has permitted the Board Director to be available to intervene when the behavioral sciences are not represented in an important initiative or when that representation is inadequate. The Board Director role also involves raising the visibility of BBCSS to the scientific community, policymakers, and other relevant stakeholders. Consequently, the Board Directors during this period have made numerous presentations at professional meetings such as the American Psychological Association. In addition to sharing the work of the board and discussing the importance of the behavioral sciences in Washington, DC, the Board Director has encouraged junior and senior academics to become involved in science policy and served as a contact for the research community in helping individuals find ways to participate. 

The Board Director regularly interfaced with Capitol Hill to brief them on reports and explain how certain reports featuring the behavioral sciences might assist Congress in their work. The Board Director also interfaced with a wide variety of federal agencies identifying issues they might have, explaining how the behavioral sciences could prove helpful, and subsequently inviting them to board meetings for discussions to encourage cross-fertilization of ideas. 

For a full view of the last five years of the board’s activities, please visit https://www.nationalacademies.org/bbcss/board-on-behavioral-cognitive-and-sensory-sciences.  Note that all publications of the National Academies are available as free downloadable PDFs.
